Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Novel Fractional Order Ground Motion Intensity Measures for High Confidence Risk Assessment of Distributed Infrastructures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Seismic risk assessment frameworks support risk-informed decision making in planning strategies for disaster prevention and mitigation. Such frameworks rely on intensity measures (IMs) to represent the strength of earthquake events, and to predict the behavior of key infrastructure components and their cascading effects on network performance and socio-economic systems. However, the current practice of adopting hazard intensity measures based on integer order derivatives or integrals of the ground motion time history is not ideal to predict infrastructure performance, and may induce significant uncertainties in the final outcome of regional risk analyses. In order to release the limitation of discrete integer order differential operations for IM characterization, this research will use new classes of spatially correlated earthquake intensity measures for regional risk assessment of infrastructures termed "รก-order IMs" based on concepts from fractional order calculus. The methodology and tools provide more accurate probabilistic predictions of the seismic response of structures and infrastructure components by significantly reducing uncertainties, thus increasing the confidence in seismic reliability and risk assessment of complex systems. This achievement will offer broad impacts to owners charged with managing risks to large distributed infrastructure systems, and the public at large who benefit from associated risk-informed decisions on mitigation and response strategies.

The project will use derivation of novel fractional order ground motion responses to characterize earthquake intensity, including identification of computationally efficient algorithms to conduct the fractional order operations. The optimal demand model form and รก-order for the IMs will be identified to enable probabilistic response prediction of a wide range of complex infrastructure constituents anticipated across a regional portfolio. The project will also develop correlated ground motion prediction equations (GMPEs) for the fractional order IMs and quantify the resulting reduced uncertainty in risk estimates (e.g. network performance, economic losses) for distributed infrastructure systems. The advancements offered by this research will afford more robust analytical methods for probabilistic characterization of earthquakes across a region, efficient modeling of the physical demand imparted on infrastructures, and increased confidence in resulting risk estimates. The overall uncertainty reduction can advance risk-informed decision making targeted at reducing human casualties, economic losses, and loss of function of infrastructure in seismic zones.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Given the devastating regional impacts and consequences that earthquakes can deliver and the ever-increasing seismic hazard exposure of built-up and population, more confident probabilistic seismic risk assessment (PSRA) of structural systems is crucial to better inform the decision-making process for the stake-holders. Particularly, ground motion intensity measure (IM) selection is a critical step in current PSRA framework, as different IM selection may lead to significantly different risk estimates. The overarching goal of this project was to develop novel ground motion intensity measures (IMs), frameworks and methodologies, as well as computational and numerical techniques to facilitate more confident seismic risk assessment of spatially distributed infrastructures.

This project developed the first ground motion prediction equation (GMPE) for the peak ground fractional order responses, PGR(α), for active shallow crustal regions, which can facilitate the hazard computability and thus the applicability of this novel IM formulation. A comprehensive IM comparative study was also carried out based on general hysteretic single-degree-of-freedom (SDOF) systems covering a wide range of structural configurations, to compare the full explanatory power potential and the applicability of different IM formulations, including those conventional IMs, recently proposed advanced IMs such as fractional order IMs and average spectral accelerations, and other potential candidate IM formulations not previously studied. The underlying mechanisms of different IM formulations were explored. Particularly, physical explanations of the fractional order IMs, PGR(α), and the spectral acceleration of fractionally damped SDOF systems, Sad(α), were provided for the first time.

In addition to the IM comparative study based on general hysteretic SDOF systems, a comprehensive investigation was conducted on optimal IM selection for bridges in liquefied and laterally spreading ground. Performance of traditional integer order IMs and recently proposed fractional IMs were assessed. Moreover, new potential fractional order IMs including cumulative absolute response (CARα) and its modified version (CAR5α), spectrum intensity for a fractionally damped SDOF system (SIdα), and fractional response of a conventional SDOF system (SIrα) were proposed. Results indicated the suitable performance of these fractional order IMs for the PSRA of extended pile-shaft supported bridges in liquefiable and laterally spreading ground.

This project also addressed a major shortcoming in the application of fractional order IMs vis-a-vis identifying the optimal order (i.e., α) for fractional order IMs. For this purpose, model order reduction techniques were proposed and tested for obtaining an optimal fractional order in Sad(α) based on characteristics of structures. Furthermore, theoretical techniques were adopted and extended to derive optimal fractional orders in fractional order IMs that are based on ground responses, such as PGR(α). Particularly, a fractional order constitutive model was used to model seismic wave propagation in rocks and soils to evaluate effect of local soil on seismic motions and identify optimal fractional orders based on characteristics of the earth in the vicinity of ground surface. A multivariate Bayesian updating framework was developed and used for parameter estimation of the fractional order soil constitutive model based on recorded data at vertical seismometer array sites in order to facilitate the application of this model in seismic and geotechnical investigations.

Additionally, this project helped to advance multivariate seismic surrogate demand modeling of general multi-response structural systems, as multiple seismic demands may relate to different failure modes in complex structural systems or across distributed infrastructure. Different statistical and machine learning techniques were tested and promising multivariate surrogate demand model (MvSDM) formulations that can better capture the nonlinear relationships among multiple predictors (e.g., the IMs and structural parameters) and emulate the correlations among multiple responses were identified for more accurate and rigorous seismic demand estimation. The MvSDMs can not only provide joint estimation of the correlated seismic demands, but also greatly reduce the computational burden in demand prediction as well as in model development and training. While bridge infrastructure was used for the case-study, the new methods and insights can have far reaching applications to other structures and systems subjected to multiple threats.  

This project filled major gaps in IM selection for risk assessment by introducing the concept of joint entropy from information theory for uncertainty quantification of multivariate data. A new entropy-based IM evaluation criterion, which can serve as the basis for IM selection, was proposed. This framework helps to yield high confidence risk estimates, such as economic losses, by selecting IM predictors that help to reduce the overall uncertainty in the coupled problem. Practical frameworks were developed to facilitate the implementation of the entropy-based IM selection PSRA and loss estimation. Compared with the traditional marginal IM evaluation criteria such as efficiency and sufficiency, the proposed entropy-based IM selection provides a holistic consideration of different sources of uncertainties. Moreover, the entropy-based uncertainty quantification can also be employed in risk assessment subjected to other types of natural hazards where uncertainty propagation is involved.
